Shanghai 200240 China Institute of Refrigeration and Cryogenics, School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, 200240, China ∗ Corresponding author. Energy conservation in buildings is of vital importance for solving the problem of global warming and energy scarcity in today's world. In this paper, we discuss the optimal control methods of the heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system using swarm intelligence algorithms to reduce energy consumption of buildings. The performances of ten optimization algorithms are compared. The results on test functions manifest the artificial bee colony algorithm (ABC) exhibits the best performance among the focused optimization algorithms. Taking a real HVAC system as an example, the holistic energy models of equipment in the HVAC system are established and validated. Then, the focused algorithms are used for the optimal control of a real HVAC system aiming at energy conservation. The simulated results based on 24-h real operation data show that the energy-saving ratio through by the ABC can reach 24.07% on average. The work in this study will contribute to the building energy conservation and carbon neutral development in the future. Keywords HVAC system Swarm intelligence algorithm Energy conversation Optimal control Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 1.1 Research background Climate change, characterized by global warming, has caused increasing concern among the public about reducing energy consumption and protecting the environment [1] [–] [3]. Buildings account for over one-third of global energy consumption and produce more than 40% of total carbon dioxide emissions [4]. Building energy conservation is a global trend in development [5]. Reducing the energy consumption of buildings is crucial for achieving the goal of sustainable cities and communities. The HVAC system is a major contributor to building energy consumption, accounting for 40–60% of a building's total energy use [6]. Optimizing the operation of HVAC systems can greatly reduce a building's energy consumption throughout its lifetime and contribute to energy savings and carbon reduction [7]. 1.2 Literature reviews 1.2.1 Energy-saving control of HVAC system For the optimal control of the HVAC system, a lot of meaningful research work has been done by previous researchers. Some established the holistic model of the system and optimized it in terms of energy saving or energy saving together with thermal comfort. With a more in-depth study of the system and advances in control technology, more and more optimization methods have been developed. Li et al. [8] proposed an agent-based distributed holistic optimization framework and presented a series of data-oriented optimization models that cater to the needs of an increasingly extensive monitoring network. Zhao et al. [9] proposed an air ventilation strategy for the energy-saving control of air-side free cooling. Chen et al. [10] investigated a reinforcement learning control strategy to minimize energy consumption and thermal discomfort in HVAC systems. Roy et al. [11] compared several machine learning classifier in the field of windows-opening detection, which aids in optimizing operational loads. Porowski [12] proposed an energy-saving optimization method based on the holistic HVAC system for the energy optimization selection. The results indicate potential reductions in annual primary energy demand of 4.4–6.5% for thermodynamic processing, and 2.5–4.3% for the combined transfer and thermodynamic processing of air. Xiong et al. [13] proposed a semi-physical model to describe the static characteristics of typical HVAC systems. A genetic algorithm was applied to find the best operating point of the HAVC system to minimize power consumption within indoor temperature constraints. They developed a method to evaluate the energy-saving potential of HVAC systems while considering the measurement uncertainties of operational data. Su et al. [14] investigated the impacts of delays in the distributed optimal control of HVAC system. In the study conducted by Shi et al. [15], a method was proposed to assess the energy-saving capacity of HVAC system, considering measurement uncertainties inherent in the operational data. Song et al. [16] proposed a novel two-stage scheduling method for the precise and private regulation of HVAC systems. This approach employed a distributed framework to enhance the accuracy and privacy of HVAC regulation. Akgüç et al. [17] proposed sophisticated transformation measures aimed at enhancing the energy efficiency of HVAC system. The findings demonstrated that in high-rise residential buildings, the implementation of a decentralized heat recovery fan system in conjunction with a demand control ventilation strategy will result in a yearly reduction of 39% in energy consumption. Schito et al. [18] conducted a multi-objective optimization study of the HVAC control system in museums, focusing on balancing the comfort of tourists, energy consumption of the building, and preservation of the integrity of artworks. Passos et al. [19] established an HVAC system model that includes sunshade, skylight, and heat pump components, and applied nonlinear optimization to determine the optimal operating parameters in an effort to reduce building energy consumption. Zeng et al. [20] employed Bayesian algorithm to reduce the calculation time of model predictive control (MPC) optimization based on HVAC system model and avoid local optimal value. Researchers have examined the physical characteristics of a specific component in the HVAC system to achieve local energy saving by optimizing its operating conditions. Sun et al. [21] applied the equilibrium optimization (EO) algorithm in solving optimal chiller loading (OCL) problem. By comparing several traditional algorithms, they found that the EO algorithm performed well in solving OCL problems on simulation experiments. Ye et al. [22] proposed a multi-layer optimal operation and management framework of water chillers that was used to operate multiple chillers and reduce system operation costs while meeting the cooling load. Deymi-Dashtebayaz et al. [23] studied the simultaneous use of economizer for air source heat pumps in a data center. Considine [24] designed a new air handing unit (AHU) inlet using numerical calculation method to reduce the system energy consumption. Wang et al. [25] built a chiller (AHU) model for energy-saving control, and an MPC strategy was proposed. Wijaya et al. [26] proposed a method that integrates Artificial Neural Network (ANN) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) to optimize the flow of the chilled water pump in order to enhance the efficiency of the building cooling system. Alavy et al. [27] found that the filter used in HVAC systems equipped with electronically commutated motor (ECM) fans exhibits a higher unit power consumption efficiency compared to those equipped with permanent split capacitor (PSC) motor fans. Raman et al. [28] established the coil model of the HVAC system, and studied the control effect and energy saving potential of MPC under different weather conditions. Wang et al. [29] proposed a sequential event-driven optimization (SEDO) strategy for the decoupling control of pipeline network in the HVAC system, which showed 4.03% energy reduction compared to the traditional strategy. The literature reviewed highlights the diverse optimization techniques utilized to reduce energy consumption in HVAC systems. While researchers have focused on optimizing the energy efficiency of the entire system or specific components, these studies still have certain limitations. Specifically, research on energy-saving optimization control of HVAC systems under multivariate conditions is insufficient. Swarm intelligence algorithms, however, present significant advantages in addressing this issue. 1.2.2 Swarm intelligence algorithm The swarm intelligence algorithm has been wildly applied in the field of optimal control of HVAC system. Zakia Afroz et al. [30] used NARX to develop a real-time prediction model for various indoor environmental parameters and HVAC energy consumption. With this model, particle swarm optimization algorithm (PSO) was applied to provide optimal control settings for HVAC system. Without compromising indoor comfort, the energy saving rate could reach 7.8%.A.U.Weerasuriya et al. [31] evaluated four optimization algorithms and three decision-making techniques for multi-objective-based optimization for a lift-up building design. A novel sensor fault detection and self-correction method based on decentralized network structure was proposed by Wang el.al [32]. to address the actual engineering problems. With this method, a revised decentralized genetic algorithm (DGA) was proposed, which can locate the faulty sensor and eliminate measurement error efficiently. Andrew Kusiak et al. [33] used neural network to establish a prediction model of HVAC system, and developed a strength multi-objective particle swarm optimization algorithm (S-MOPSO) algorithm to obtain the optimal solution. This method reduces the energy consumption of the HVAC system while maintaining indoor thermal comfort. Based on a database, Zhou et al. [34] used the Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) neural network to establish the load forecasting model of HVAC system. The ABC and the PSO are used to optimize the parameters of the model. Li et al. [35] introduced a revised PSO algorithm based on the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model. This new algorithm offered advantages in terms of both low computational cost and high optimization performance. Yu et al. [36] established a model of an HVAC system incorporating a double-circuit cooling coil and proposed a method based on PSO for optimizing the flow and temperature of the chilled water. Yelisetti et al. [37] established a mathematical model for calculating the energy consumption cost of residential buildings. They utilized various optimization algorithms based on swarm intelligence to optimize different building parameters and evaluated the effectiveness and performance of each algorithm. Deng et al. [38] presented a novel optimization solution utilizing Quantum Annealing for MPC of Rooftop Units (RTU), characterized by a faster calculation speed and improved accuracy. Zhang et al. [39] compared ANN and GA in the regulation of indoor air quality, with the proposed indexes that effectively demonstrate the influence of pollutant distribution on the well-being of the occupants. Chen et al. [40] used two swarm intelligence algorithms to locate the pollutant sources of unknown height in an unventilated indoor environment. Kumar et al. [41] used a hybrid model based on PSO and extreme learning machine (ELM) to predict the indoor temperature and energy consumption of the HVAC system. The aforementioned literature review emphasizes the utilization of swarm intelligence algorithms to optimize HVAC systems. Various algorithms, including the PSO, the S-MOPSO, and the ABC, have been employed in conjunction with mathematical models and neural networks to accomplish energy conservation, fault detection, and load prediction. Despite several accomplishments, there remain certain research gaps. Certain classical swarm intelligence algorithms have yet to be applied to HVAC systems, and a comparison among different swarm intelligence algorithms has not been performed. 1.3 The overview of this paper Based on the analysis of the current state of research concerning the optimal control of the HVAC system, previous researchers have done significant work. The swarm intelligence algorithm has been applied in building modelling and optimizing control. While many optimization algorithms have been applied to the optimal control of the HVAC systems, there is a lack of research that compares the performance of different swarm intelligence algorithms for optimizing HVAC systems with regard to energy savings. By conducting a comparative analysis of the optimization effects of different algorithms on test functions and applying these algorithms to a comprehensive model of an HVAC system, the present study endeavors to address this research gap. The structure of this paper is presented in Fig. 1 .The main contributions of this paper are as follows: 1) The performances of ten types of swarm intelligence optimization algorithms on the test function are evaluated in terms of optimization ability, stability and efficiency. To facilitate a fair comparison, a weighted comparison method is proposed and used to compare the algorithms. 2) The performances of ten optimization algorithms in the holistic energy consumption model under different conditions is discussed, and the ABC is applied simulatively to a HVAC system for typical daily analysis to verify its energy saving potential. 2 Comprehensive performance of the focused swarm intelligence algorithms 2.1 The focused swarm intelligence algorithms The swarm intelligence algorithm involves a series of steps, including the initialization of particles, the update of particles, the evaluation of particles, the determination of whether termination conditions have been met, and the termination or continuation of the cycle, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . Initializing particles refers to the process of distributing particles within a specified range in order to approximate the desired solution, using predetermined distribution rules. Updating particles involves using prescribed rules to modify the position of particles based on their own historical fitness values and interactions with other particles. Evaluating particles involves assessing the fitness of each particle using a chosen method, such as an objective function. The cycle will be terminated and the particle with the highest fitness will be output as the desired solution if the specified termination conditions are met. If the termination conditions are not met, the cycle will continue. Based on different objects of imitation, a lot of swarm intelligence algorithms have been developed. The algorithms discussed in this paper are listed in Table 1 , including classical methods such as the PSO, the AFSA as well as the newer algorithms the SBO and the SSA2020. Some of the optimization algorithms have simple rules that govern their behavior, for example the PSO. Other algorithms employ a population-based approach, wherein the population is divided into different categories with different behaviors, for instance the ABC, the WPS, the GWO, the SBO, and the SSA2020. Additionally, some algorithms employ a strategy wherein individuals are allowed to choose different behaviors randomly or according to certain rules, such as the AFSA, the CSA, the SSA2017, the WOA. Details about these algorithms can be found in the appendix. 2.2 Test functions The optimization control problem for HVAC systems possesses characteristics of high dimensionality and multiple local optima [37,52]. Therefore, the performance of optimization algorithms for HVAC system optimization problems is validated by comparing their performance on test functions that exhibit these properties. Test functions are also a commonly used method for validating the properties of optimization algorithms [53,54]. To fully investigate the performance of the optimization algorithms, unimodal, multimodal, separable, and no-separable test functions are used. Test functions and their characteristics are shown in Table 2 . 2.3 Performance on test functions 2.3.1 Parameter setting In swarm intelligence algorithms, the number of individuals and the maximum number of iterations are significant parameters. To ensure consistent evaluation criteria when comparing different algorithms, the number of individuals in the population and the maximum number of iterations are set to 50 and 500, respectively. The test functions have a dimensionality of 30. The parameter settings of these optimization algorithms are determined in terms of their best performance, adopting the common settings in applications or the settings that have been proven to be more effective. The model parameters of algorithms are shown in Table 3 . 2.3.2 Convergency analysis Fig. 3 presents the convergence curves of the focused algorithms on various test functions. The x-axis represents the number of iterations of the optimization algorithm, and the y-axis represents the minimum value that the optimization algorithm has found. The convergence curves suggest that most of the algorithms perform well on the simple unimodal and separable test functions F1–F6. However, some of the algorithms struggle to locate the optimal solution on the multimodal functions F7–F10, which have multiple extreme points. Among all the algorithms, the ABC shows a strong ability for optimization. It achieves the best results on six test functions and performed well on the others. In particular, on the complex multimodal functions F7, F8 and F9, the ABC is the only algorithm that is able to quickly locate the optimal solution. It can be inferred from the convergence curve that the main advantage of the ABC algorithm is its ability to converge faster in the early stages and avoid getting trapped in local optima. As a result, it outperforms the other algorithms on the complex multimodal functions F7, F8 and F9, being the only one capable of quickly locating the optimal solution. 2.3.3 Performance and analysis Fifty repeated simulation experiments of the optimization algorithm are carried out for each test function. To evaluate the comprehensive performance of the algorithms, three indexes, e.g., convergence time, fitness and stability, are suggested. Totally fifty times of tests have been made. The mean convergence time (MCT) and mean fitness (MF) of each algorithm are obtained based on the results of all the tests. The stability of the algorithm could be indicated by the variances of fitness (VF) of all the tests. The test results are given in Table 4 . It can be seen from Table 4 that the PSO converged in the shortest time. This may due to the simplicity of its iteration rules. In addition, the solution time of the WPS, the CSA, and the WPS is also shorter than that of the other algorithms, demonstrating their efficiency. The SBO took significantly longer to reach convergence, which may be attributed to the repeated random steps when updating the location of each individual. The performance of the algorithms on high-dimensional test functions varied. Among the ten objective functions, the ABC demonstrated the best performance on most test functions, outperforming the other swarm intelligence algorithms included in the comparison. The SBO, the SSA2017, and the WPA algorithms also performed well on some functions. The variance between the results indicates the stability of the algorithm. The algorithm with the higher MF also has the higher VF, possibly due to the large fitness when optimization fails. To evaluate the comprehensive performance of the algorithms, a scoring system is used based on the sorted results of each performance index. The performance scores of the ten algorithms are presented in Table 5 , where the algorithm with the highest value is assigned a score of 1 point, followed by 2 points for the second highest value, and so on. In engineering applications, time requirements for algorithms are often of the lower priority compared to accuracy and stability. Therefore, a weighting system is developed based on actual engineering experience to incorporate these factors into the total score for each algorithm. The weight for MCT is set to 0.2, and the weight for MF and VF is set to 0.4. The total score for each algorithm is calculated by adding the scores on the test functions, with a maximum possible score of 100 points. As shown in Fig. 4 , the ABC achieves the highest score, while the WOA, PSO, and CSA algorithms showed poor performance. (1) S c o r e = ∑ 1 10 0.2 × s c o r e ( M C T ) + 0.4 × s c o r e ( M F ) + 0.4 × s c o r e ( V F ) Through analyzing the performance of the focused optimization algorithms on test functions, the ABC has been found more suitable for optimization problems in HVAC systems. This is mainly attributed to the ABC algorithm's capability of conserving computational resources by only maintaining the quantity and distribution of particles, rather than maintaining particle velocity and other information. Additionally, the algorithm effectively exploits global information to prevent falling into local optima. To validate this point, an energy consumption model based on a real HVAC system was established to verify the performance of the swarm intelligence algorithm. 3 Case study This section provides a detailed description of the steps involved in developing, establishing, and validating the model for the HVAC system studied, which is installed in a hotel located in Quzhou, Zhejiang, China. The system consists of three chillers, four chilled water pumps, four cooling water pumps, and three cooling towers, as illustrated in Fig. 5 and Table 6 . The chilled water pumps are connected in parallel, while the cooling water pumps are connected in series with the cooling towers and chillers. Only one of the two cooling water pumps connected to the first chiller is operational. The water flow and temperature of each part are collected by corresponding sensors. During normal operation of the HVAC system, one cooling water pump and one chilled water pump are kept in a standby state. The standby cooling water pump is the one connected to the first chiller, and the cooling water pumps are arranged in a series configuration with the cooling towers and chillers. 3.1 Models and objective function In order to accurately model the HVAC system, it is imperative to establish models for the coefficient of performance (COP) of the chillers, the models of water pumps, and the models of cooling towers. The necessary data for this task are collected from the Quzhou hotel. 90% of the data used to establish the model, while the remaining 10% are employed for validation. 3.1.1 Model for chiller The chiller's coefficient of performance can be expressed as: (2) C O P = r ( t c + 273.15 t e + 273.15 − 1 ) r + a 1 ⋅ t c + 273.15 t e + 273.15 − a 2 where, r is the load rate of the chiller, t c is the condensation temperature ( ° C ), t e is the evaporation temperature ( ° C ), a 1 and a 2 are parameters to be determined. When these parameters are determined, other required physical quantities are obtained according to the conservation of mass and the conservation of energy. P c h i l l e r could be calculated by Equations (2) and (7). P c h i l l e d _ w a t e r _ p u m p and P c o o l i n g _ w a t e r _ p u m p could be calculated with Equation (9). P c o o l i n g t o w e r could be calculated with Equation (15). The goal of the optimization algorithm is to find the appropriate G w , c and T w , e , L that minimize the energy consumption of the system. The system energy consumption calculation process is illustrated in Fig. 10 . After sensing the parameters Q L o a d , t , and h u , the current chilled water inlet temperature and the set chilled water output temperature are utilized to calculate the chilled water flow, power consumption, and chiller evaporation temperature t e . The cooling water flow, power consumption, and cooling tower energy consumption are calculated based on the current cooling water flow rate. The chiller power consumption is obtained by iterating the calculation of the evaporation temperature computed from the circulating cold water flow rate and determining the condensation temperature. Finally, the power consumption of the entire system is obtained along with the current parameter settings. The initial strategy for this system did not involve optimization and instead relied on a fixed-point strategy that maintained the chilled water outlet temperature at 7 °C while operating the chilled water and cooling water pumps at full flow rate, which corresponds to 50Hz. The cooling load is distributed evenly among the operational chillers. Considering the safe use restrictions of the actual equipment, the boundary conditions of some important parameters are set as follows: 3.2 Results and discussions 3.2.1 Performance on target function With the holistic model of the HVAC system available, the ten swarm intelligence algorithms are applied to minimize power consumption with optimal operating parameters. The effectiveness of these algorithms is verified through four cases. The baseline for each case is the fixed-point strategy, and the experimental conditions are based on actual operating data from the system. The optimal control points for each case including chilled water outlet temperature environmental temperature and cooling water flow are presented as a* and b* in Table 11 . The ambient temperature, ambient humidity, cooling load, actual power, predicted power, and prediction error are also presented in Table 11. Each algorithm run 10 times for each case. The total time consumed, mean power, and the variance of the results are listed in the Table 12 . The model developed in section 3.1 demonstrates strong predictive ability for the holistic energy consumption of the system, with the prediction error mostly below 5%, and the largest error being 5.45%. The optimal chilled water outlet temperature is higher than the fixed point of 7 °C, and the optimal cooling water flow is 23.05%–32.7% lower than the fixed point of 200 m 3 / h . It strikes a balance between increasing the evaporating temperature to reduce the energy consumption of the chiller and decreasing the flow rate to reduce the energy consumption of the water pump while lowering the condensing temperature. It can be observed that almost all of the ten swarm intelligence algorithms successfully identified the control points that minimize energy consumption for cases 1 and 2, with energy-saving rate of 22.5% and 10.5%. This may be attributed to the simple structure of the single unit with only two parameters. The AFSA, the GWO and the SBO may occasionally fail in optimization, resulting in a higher mean power and variance. SBO exhibits slightly inferior performance in both optimization capability and stability. For cases 3 and 4, as multiple chillers with local optimal control points are involved, the differences between algorithms are highlighted. It can be seen that different swarm intelligence algorithms were able to reduce energy consumption in the system compared to the original control strategy, although there were variations in energy-saving performance. The ABC algorithm achieved the best energy-saving effect in both cases, with energy-saving rates of 21.3% and 24.7%, indicating that it reaches the global optimal control point in each experiment. Among the algorithms, the CSA, the SSA2017, and the PSO have better results in terms of total time consumed for the three cases. The time spent by the algorithms is generally acceptable, with the exception of AFSA and WPA. Comparing cases 1, 2 with cases 3, 4, it can be observed that as the load increases, multiple chillers were turned on, which presented certain challenges for the optimization process. 3.2.2 Typical day analysis To investigate the energy-saving potential of the ABC in the HVAC system, data from a typical day of operation at the Quzhou hotel is used. Fig. 11 shows the ambient temperature and humidity over a 24-h period. The meteorological conditions on this day are representative of the typical summer climate in Quzhou, with high temperatures and low humidity during the day and low temperatures and high humidity at night. The ABC is applied to optimize the HVAC system on a typical day, and the results are shown in Fig. 12 . The air conditioning system at the hotel operates 24 h per day. The variation in the cooling load follows the changes in meteorological conditions, with a high load during the day and a low load at night. The optimization algorithm demonstrated a good energy-saving effect, with a potential energy-saving rate of 20%–30%. When the temperature is high throughout the day and the load is high, the energy-saving rate reached 27%. At night, when the cooling load was low, the energy-saving rate is around 20%. There is variance in energy-saving rate with difference cooling load. A possible explanation is that when the cooling load is low, the large flow rate and the small temperature difference of unoptimized condition is more serious, bringing additional energy waste. For the whole day, the energy-saving rate is 24.07%. The system COP for this typical day is 3.67 with optimal control, 2.78 with fixed-point control. The optimized chilled water outlet temperature and cooling water flow rate for the typical day are presented in the Fig. 13 . Compared to the original fixed frequency control strategy, the average chilled water outlet temperature is 0.95 °C higher than the fixed value, while the cooling water flow rate is 42.9 m 3 / h lower than the fixed value. This has resulted in an increased COP of the chiller and reduced energy consumption of the water pump, thus improving the overall system efficiency. 4 Conclusion This study applied ten swarm intelligence-based algorithms to investigate their potential for energy-saving optimization control in an HVAC system. A holistic model of an HVAC system in Quzhou, China is developed and validated using field data. Models for each component of the system, including the chillers, pumps, and cooling towers, are also obtained and verified. The performance of the algorithms is evaluated using ten test functions with different characteristics. A weighted algorithm is proposed based on practical engineering experience, and the results indicated that the Artificial Bee Colony algorithm (ABC) performed the best on the test functions after the weighted calculation of each index. When applied to the holistic model, the ABC achieved the highest energy-saving rate and lowest variance across four cases. On a typical day analysis, the total energy-saving rate of the ABC is 24.07%. In future work, we plan to improve the accuracy of the HVAC system model by refining the modeling method and improving the quality of the data. The aim is to investigate the use of more advanced swarm intelligence algorithms for energy-saving optimization control in HVAC systems and to apply these algorithms in real control settings. Appendix PSO： The PSO simulates the foraging behavior of birds to solve the optimal solution of single-mode or multi-mode problems. This is a classical swarm intelligence algorithm. In the algorithm, each particle represents a candidate solution. By constantly moving with its historical optimal position and the global optimal position, the optimal solution of the objective function within the parameter range is searched. Its basic steps are as follows: Step 1: Initializes particles in parameter space. For the r-dimensional problem, each particle has R components, which represents the position of the particle in the parameter space. The position of particles can be generated randomly or according to a specific distribution. The number of particles is an optional parameter in the algorithm. For a particle swarm containing N particles, it can be described by the following formula: X = { x 1 , x 2 , x 3 , ⋯ , x N } x i = ( x i 1 , x i 2 , x i 3 , ⋯ , x i r ) , i = 1,2,3 , ⋯ , N Step 2: Evaluate particles. The fitness can be obtained by substituting the position of each example into the objective function f ( x ) . Each particle has a historical optimal position p h i s t o r y , and all particles have a global optimal position p g l o b a l . p h i s t o r y i = { p h i s t o r y i , f ( p h i s t o r y i ) ≤ f ( x i ) x i , f ( p h i s t o r y i ) > f ( x i ) , i = 1,2,3 , ⋯ , N p g l o b a l = x i , i f f ( x i ) = min ( f ( x 1 ) , f ( x 2 ) , f ( x 3 ) , ⋯ , f ( x n ) ) Step 3: Update particles. According to the historical optimal value p h i s t o r y of the particles and the global optimal value p g l o b a l , and the parameters set by the algorithm, the particles are given a moving speed v t to update the position of the particles. c 1 and c 2 is the acceleration factor, determining the speed at which a particle approach p h i s t o r y and p g l o b a l . r 1 and r 2 are random numbers satisfying uniform distribution [0,1]. v i t + 1 = v i t + c 1 r 1 ( p h i s t o r y i , t − x i t ) + c 2 r 2 ( p g l o b a l t − x i t ) x i t + 1 = x i t + v i t + 1 Step 4: Evaluate whether the termination conditions are met. Termination conditions generally include reaching the maximum number of iterations or not significantly improving the solution within a certain number of iterations. If the termination condition is reached, the optimal solution is output; otherwise, proceed to step 2. AFSA The AFSA simulates the foraging behavior of fish groups to achieve optimization according to the characteristic that the place with the largest number of fish in the water area is the place with the largest amount of nutrients in the water area. The algorithm mainly uses the three basic behaviors of fish: foraging, crowding and tail chasing. It uses the top-down optimization mode to start from constructing the bottom behavior of the individual, and through the local optimization of each individual in the fish school, to achieve the purpose of highlighting the global optimal value in the group. Step 1: Initialize settings, including the population size N, the initial position of every artificial fish, the visual field of artificial fish V i s u a l f i l e d , step size S t e p , crowding factor δ and repetition times t r y n u m b e r . Step 2: Calculate the fitness value of each individual in the initial fish school, and assign the optimal artificial fish state and its value to the bulletin board. Step 3: For each fish, the objective function is utilized to calculate the results of the following four behaviors: foraging, clustering, tail chasing, and random. Perform the behavior in which the result is the best. Foraging behavior: The artificial fish randomly selects a state in its field of vision and compares its fitness with its position to judge whether it is moving forward. If there is no advance, continue to randomly select and compare in the field of view, unless try number is reached. X j = X i + V i s u a l f i l e d * R a n d o m X i t + 1 = X i t + X j − X i t ‖ X j − X i t ‖ * S t e p * R a n d o m , i f f ( X j ) < f ( X i ) Clustering behavior: The artificial fish searches the number of partners η f and the center position X c in the current field of view. If f ( X c ) ∙ η f < δ ∙ f ( X i ) , it indicates that the center position of the partner is in good condition and not too crowded. Then move one step towards the center position of the partner. X i t + 1 = X i t + X c − X i t ‖ X c − X i t ‖ * S t e p * R a n d o m , i f f ( X c ) ∙ η f < δ ∙ f ( X i ) Tail chasing behavior: The artificial fish explores the optimal position X v b e s t of the neighboring fish and the number of partners η f in V i s u a l f i l e d . If f ( X v b e s t ) ∙ η f < δ ∙ f ( X i ) , the current position moves to the optimal neighbor fish. X i t + 1 = X i t + X v b e s t − X i t ‖ X v b e s t − X i t ‖ * S t e p * R a n d o m , i f f ( X v b e s t ) ∙ η f < δ ∙ f ( X i ) Random behavior: This is default behavior of foraging behavior, which means that artificial fish move randomly in the field of vision. X i t + 1 = X i t + S t e p * R a n d o m Step 4: After each running action, the currently found optimal value will be updated. If the iteration end condition is met, the cycle will end and the optimal value of the current record will be output; otherwise, continue. ABC The standard ABC divides the artificial bee colony into three categories: employed bee, onlooker bee, and scout bee by simulating the honey-collecting mechanism of the actual bee. The goal of the whole colony is to find the largest nectar source. In the standard ABC, bees use the previous honey source information to find new honey sources and share the honey source information with observation bees; Observe the bees waiting in the hive and look for new honey sources according to the information shared by the bees; The task of detecting bees is to find a new valuable source of honey. They randomly look for a source of honey near the hive. Step 1: Initialization. Within the range of parameter selection, randomly generate food sources equal to the number of scout bees. Each food source corresponds to a solution vector of the optimization problem. x m is a solution vector, l i and u i are Upper and lower limits of the i t h dimension. x m i = l i + r a n d ( 0,1 ) ∙ ( u i − l i ) Step 2: Employed Bees Phase. Employed bees look for food sources with more nectar near the food sources in their memory, and assess the fitness of new food source. v m is the position of the new food source, φ m i is a random number within the range [−a, a], x k is a food source randomly selected within their memory. v m i = x m i + φ m i ( x m i − x k i ) Step 3: Onlooker Bees Phase. Onlooker Bees follow employed bees according to the fitness of the latter. For employed bees, the higher the fitness, the greater the probability of being followed. For each food source, the probability of being followed p m can be calculated by the following formula: p m = f ( x m ) ∑ m = 1 N f ( x m ) Therefore, food sources with higher fitness will attract more onlookers. Step 4: Scout Bees Phase. Employed bees that have not been promoted since a certain number of iterations will become scout bees. They will abandon their original food source and find a new solution. Step 5: Record the global optimal solution and judge whether the termination condition is met, so as to judge whether to enter the cycle or output the optimal solution. WPS The wolf swarm algorithm solves the optimization problem by initializing the wolf swarm, competing for the wolf king, calling from the wolf king, besieging prey, and updating the wolf swarm. The steps of the wolf swarm algorithm are as follows: Step 1: Initialization. Let the scale of the artificial wolf pack be N, the dimension of the search space be D, and the spatial position of the ith artificial wolf can be expressed as: X i = ( x i 1 , x i 2 , x i 3 , ⋯ , x i D ) , 1 ≤ i ≤ N x i d = x min + r a n d * ( x max − x min ) Step 2: Competition for the wolf king. Select Q artificial wolves with the best moderate value (the best position) as competitors. The artificial wolf searches around them. Whenever the fitness value of the searched position is higher than the original position, it updates its current position. Each wolf repeated the search until the maximum number of searches was reached. After the search, the wolf king has the highest location fitness. The best (Q-1) artificial wolf other than the wolf king is regarded as a probe wolf. The wolf wanders around at random. Step 3: The wolf king starts the calling behavior by howling and calls up the surrounding K fierce wolves to move closer to the position of the head wolf. g t is the position of the wolf king, the fierce wolf move step length is s t e p m , then the position of the fierce wolf i at the t+1 iteration in the d-dimensional variable space is expressed as: x i t + 1 = x i t + s t e p m * ( g t − x i t ) | g t − x i t | During the fierce wolf's attack, if the position of the fierce wolf i is better than that of the wolf king, the wolf king will make a calling behavior, otherwise continue to attack until the distance from the head wolf is less than the set distance. Step 4: Besieging prey. The fierce wolf close to the prey and the probe wolf are combined to besiege the prey, and the position of the head wolf closest to the prey is regarded as the moving position of the prey. Let the position of the prey in the d-dimensional space be G d k , fierce wolf attack step length is s t e p a ,the siege behavior of wolves can be expressed as: x i t + 1 = x i t + λ ∙ s t e p a ∙ | G t − x i t | Step 5: Remove u artificial wolves with the worst objective function in the algorithm, and then randomly generate u new artificial wolves. Judge whether the termination conditions are met. GWO The algorithm is an optimization search method inspired by the predatory activities of gray wolves. It includes the steps of the gray wolf's social hierarchy, tracking, encircling, and attacking prey. The specific steps are as follows. Step 1: Initialize the population and build the gray wolf social hierarchy model. Calculate the fitness of each individual in the population, and mark the 3 Gy wolves with the best fitness as α , β , δ , and the rest as ω . The optimization process of the GWO is mainly guided by the best three solutions ( α , β , δ ) in each generation of the population. Step 2: Encircling Prey. The gray wolf will gradually approach the prey and surround it when preying on it. The mathematical model of this behavior is as follows: X t + 1 = X t − ( 2 a ∘ r 1 − a ) ∘ ( 2 r 2 ∘ X p t − X t ) r 1 and r 2 are random vectors in [0, 1]. ∘ is the hadamard product operator. In the whole iteration process, a decreases linearly from 2 to 0. X p is the position of the prey and X is the position of the wolf. Step 3: Hunting. To simulate the search behavior of gray wolves, it is assumed that α , β , δ have a strong ability to identify the location of potential prey. Therefore, during each iteration, the best 3 Gy wolves in the current population are retained, and then the positions of other gray wolves are updated according to their position information. Step 4: Judge whether the termination condition is reached. If not, continue hunting. CSA One of the intelligent behaviors of crows is that they hide their surplus food in a specific hiding place and recall the location of food when necessary. In addition, crows have greedy habit. They will follow other crows to find their hiding places. If a crow finds a hiding place for other crows, it will steal the hidden food. The Crow search algorithm imitates the crow's behavior of hiding and eating to solve the optimization problem. Its basic steps are as follows: Step 1: Initialization. Define decision variables: the number of crows N , the maximum number of iterations i t e r max , flight distance f l , and perception probability AP. Step 2: Initialize crow's position and memory. N crows are randomly distributed in a d-dimensional search space. In the first iteration, it is assumed that crows hide their food in the initial position. Step 3: Update crow position. In each iteration, crow i will randomly select a crow j to track. If crow i is not detected, it flies to the hiding place of crow j; Otherwise, crow i will fly one step at random. x i t + 1 = { x i t + r i ⋅ f l i t ⋅ ( m j t − x i t ) , r j ≥ A P j t a r a n d o m p o s i t i o n , o t h e r w i s e If the new position adaptation value of crow I is higher, it will fly to the new position, otherwise, it will stay in its original position. Step 4: Update the fitness value of each crow's new position and check whether the termination conditions are met. SSA2017 The salp swarm algorithm simulates the group behavior of the slaps chain, in which leaders explore the holistic situation while followers fully explore the local area, so that the chain has strong global exploration and local development ability. Step 1: Initialization. Suppose all salps are randomly distributed in the solution space. According to the fitness value, the swarm of salps is sorted, and the position of the salp with the best fitness is set as the current food position. Step 2: Update position. Rank the remaining n-1 individuals according to their fitness. The first half with the highest fitness is set as leader and the rest as followers. coredata.dc:description: Energy conservation in buildings is of vital importance for solving the problem of global warming and energy scarcity in today's world. In this paper, we discuss the optimal control methods of the heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) system using swarm intelligence algorithms to reduce energy consumption of buildings. The performances of ten optimization algorithms are compared. The results on test functions manifest the artificial bee colony algorithm (ABC) exhibits the best performance among the focused optimization algorithms. Taking a real HVAC system as an example, the holistic energy models of equipment in the HVAC system are established and validated. Then, the focused algorithms are used for the optimal control of a real HVAC system aiming at energy conservation. The simulated results based on 24-h real operation data show that the energy-saving ratio through by the ABC can reach 24.07% on average. The work in this study will contribute to the building energy conservation and carbon neutral development in the future.
coredata.dc:title: Research on optimal control of HVAC system using swarm intelligence algorithms
